title: Strike action could happen in Guernsey
text:
Strike action could be on the horizon for one of Guernsey's biggest public sector unions.
71% Guernsey's voting Unite members rejected a new pension deal The deal will see many staff continue to work until they are 70 while emergency service employees will collect their pensions at 63.
Last night 25 local representatives from Unite met to discuss the next steps in a long running dispute with the States.
Unite's Regional representative for Guernsey, Bob Lanning says workers are demanding action now, but there is a 'longer route ahead.
He added that he wants to know how the States can legally enforce the changes.
Play video Unite representatives in some workplaces will be asking members to take part in a ballot to see if they are interested in strike action.
The new pension plan could also see staff contributing 7% of their earnings to their pension scheme.
Under the proposals around just under 2,000 States employees would be able to keep their final salary pension scheme.
Last updated Wed 7 Oct 2015 Politics Guernsey
